Award.AwardTitle: Conference Participation Support Proposal - 21st Annual Conference Experience for Undergraduates; Waikoloa, HI, 23 - 27 October 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide funds to partially support the 21st annual Conference Experience for Undergraduates (CEU), which is held as part of the Fall Meeting of the APS Division of Nuclear Physics. This year's meeting will be held jointly with the Physical Society of Japan in Waikoloa, Hawaii October 23 - 27, 2018. The CEU is a natural venue for students who have had an undergraduate research experience to present the results of their research and interact with other students as well as faculty and senior researchers. The CEU has been immensely successful in fostering this interaction, which helps students to have a broad introduction and exposure to research across nuclear physics, and to enable senior researchers to get to know some of the junior future leaders. Partial support will be provided for approximately 26 undergraduate students, out of a planned total of 136.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: This proposal funded undergraduate students participating in the Division of Nuclear Physics (DNP) as part of the 21st annual Conference Experience for Undergradues (CEU). 

Intellectual Merit: Undergraduate conference participants received a broad and comprehensive exposure to the field of nuclear physics as a result of being exposed to cutting-edge research in all areas of the field and through meeting individual members of the community conducting this research. Students were able to present their research in an undergraduate only poster session and participate fully in the national DNP conference of the American Physical Society. 

Broader Impact: The largest impact of this grant is on human resources. Encouraging these students into Science Technology Engineering and Math (STEM) fields is a recognized National need. Undergraduate student participating in a national meeting, at which they meet many professional physicists and one another, receive broad exposure to the quality and variety of cutting edge research being conducted in the US and abroad and see how scientific results are disseminated at a professional meeting through formal presentation and informal conversation.  This participation can provide  positive, life changing experience, having potentially strong influence on graduate school and career decisions students will make in the coming years.
